Bridge mess cripples Mumbai\u2019s infra.description: Mumbai's municipal corporation has been shutting down bridges and foot over-bridges one after another, choking traffic on arterial roads even as the monsoon is almost here. The reason given is that these structures have become old and dilapidated. But the question on everyone' Why has the BMC woken up all of a sudden? "This appears to be a knee-jerk reaction following the fatal Himalaya FOB crash at CSMT in March," says G R Vora, a member of the F-North ward Citizens' Federation and resident of Sion where two FOBs at King Circle were recently shut for inspection. "Civic officials first neglected bridge maintenance and have now realized that many are beyond repair and have to be pulled down." Of the 29 bridges classified as 'dangerous', eight have been razed and over a dozen shut for vehicular and pedestrian movement. The two FOBs at King Circle are not part of the 'dangerous' bridges list, but have been shut after the re-audit dound some damages in the structures. Additional municipal commissioner Vijay Singhal, in charge of civic bridges department, says: "We did not want to close all these bridges, but were left with no choice. We cannot play with people's lives. We are looking at alternative traffic arrangements and solutions." Short-staffed departmentA study of the reasons for the sudden closures exposes serious gaps in the functioning of the country's richest municipal body-to start with, a severely short-staffed bridges department that is barely six years old. Of the sanctioned 104 posts, 47 are vacant. This means there are only 57 staffers overseeing 300-plus bridges, FOBs, vehicular and pedestrian subways and skywalks, including the 29 'dangerous' bridges aged between two and six decades. The numerous vacancies in existing posts seems ironic considering the department has asked for an extra 116 new posts to be created. Prior to 2013, city bridges were maintained by the roads and traffic department and an assistant engineer (bridges) would report to the road department head. But with more bridges coming up across the city, the need was felt for a dedicated bridges department. The first chief engineer of the new department was S O Kori, who is currently behind bars in the Himalaya FOB crash incident for 'lack of supervision'. Nitai Mehta, founder and managing trustee of NGO Praja Foundation whose recent report analysed the staff crunch in BMC, says: "The fundamental problem is the corporation today is only fire-fighting instead of looking at long-term solutions...Many of these bridges are a part of the old infrastructure and need to undergo periodic inspections and maintenance. Instead, the administration is focused on constructing new infrastructure to create ribbon-cutting moments." Also, the number of vehicles on roads is rapidly increasing, putting pressure on infrastructure. As on March 2019, there were over 36.4 lakh vehicles on city roads (up from 33.5 lakh in 2018), of which 58.6% were two-wheelers, 29.3% cars, jeeps, station wagons, 3.7% taxis/cabs, 5.8% autos, 0.4% buses and 2.2% goods vehicles. 'Few checks, bad upkeep'BMC's bridges manual, that was brought out in 2011, says assistant engineers must inspect bridges twice a year-in April and in October. Accordingly, major/minor repairs, if required, need to be taken up. The inquiry conducted by the civic vigilance department in the Himalaya FOB crash incident blamed the department for not following the manual. The first-ever audit done by the department was only after the tragic 2016 Mahad bridge collapse on Savitri river in Raigad. The audit covered 253 brid- ges-150 in western suburbs, 64 in eastern suburbs and 39 in the island city. The report was delayed and it was only after the pedestrian section of Andheri's Gokhale bridge collapsed on July 3, 2018, that corporators demanded its immediate release. The report had recommended demolition of 14 'dangerous' bridges-six in western suburbs, five in eastern suburbs and three in the island city-major repairs for 61 structures and minor repairs for 107. But six months later, in March 2019, when the Himalaya FOB, which was found to be in a 'good condition' in the audit, crashed, a re-audit was sought. This re-audit added 15 more bridges to the 'dangerous' list taking the total number to 29. The BMC has spent nearly Rs 2.5 crore on the structural audits of the bridges. A senior, independent expert underscored the significance of such checks. "Usually after a bridge is constructed, there is need for periodic maintenance and repairs after 30 years. But it is often seen that during repairs, new layers are added without removing the earlier layers, which adds to the dead load," says Shirish Sukhtame, former president of Practicing Engineers Architects and Town Planners Association. Most bridges have a deck type construction with two girders as side support, but the deck in between, on which people walk, is much thinner. "During structural audits, owing to this layer over layer, the welding joints are not accessible. There is a need to routinely check the structure and replace anything if required, but part by part, without inconveniencing the public," adds Sukhtame. Clearly, such a system is absent. Chetan Raikar, a structural engineer, also suggests fundamental changes in the work culture. "Engineers should get both classroom and on-job training once they are inducted," he adds. Satta Market.description: BHOPAL: This assembly  is turning out to be a nail-biter. The Bhopal satta bazaar that gave BJP a good chance three weeks ago is suddenly abuzz about Congress’ prospects. As per the bookies, till about a month ago, if a person placed a bet of Rs 10,000 on BJP, he would get Rs 11,000 if the party returned to power. And anyone who bet Rs 4,400 on Congress would get Rs 10,000 if the opposition wins. This week, bookies say, they are taking bets on number of seats and not on who would form the government. “In case no party gets absolute majority, or if the scoreline is too close,” explained a bookie. “We do not want to say which party will form the government. The bets are open. The satta market is running good this poll season, as it is a thrilling contest,” he added. Bookies told TOI that satta trends may not reflect the actual situation on the ground, but the market is accepting bets on 116-plus seats for Congress and 102 or more for ruling BJP. “Anyone who bets successfully on BJP or Congress will double his money,” a bookie said, adding that this trend may change just as suddenly in the next few days as campaigning gets more intense. The same bookie had told TOI around a month ago that rates may vary once candidates are finalised by the parties, “but we expect the trend to remain the same”. The satta market runs into crores in every election. Bets are placed not just over phone, but also on websites and apps, leaving almost no room for police to track down bookies and those placing bets. Probably, this is why no gang has been busted in the state so far for running an election betting racket. At least two cases of betting are registered daily in Bhopal, but the people pulling the strings of the racket in poll season are yet to be caught. Police officers say it is getting increasingly difficult to nab such gangs because they are constantly on the move. “Online betting can be operated even from a moving car, a café or any public place anywhere in the country. Those running the betting in Bhopal may be sitting anywhere on the globe,” said an officer. SP-south Rahul Kumar Lodha said a special campaign is being run against criminals involved in gambling and betting ahead of elections. “These criminals are made to sign bonds to prevent them from committing such crimes in the future. Raids are being conducted on specific tips. A list of habitual offenders is being prepared by police stations to curb such illegal activities,” he said. ASP-crime Rashmi Mishra said the crime branch has activated its network of informers prior to elections to keep an eye on betting. “It is difficult to crack online betting and gambling rackets, but police take action against criminals on specific inputs. For instance, we were tipped off on Monday night about a betting den in Kolar. It was raided but no such activity was found,” Mishra said, adding that the cyber cell is constantly on the lookout for websites and mobile apps used by betting rackets. Mumbai: Nab principal in sex harassment.description: MUMBAI: Members of two student organizations protested at a popular college in a western suburb on Tuesday and demanded that the principal be suspended and arrested over a pending sexual harassment complaint filed this February by a psychologist who was visiting the institution for a conference. A similar complaint was made against the principal by a teacher of the college where he was previously employed. The principal has denied the allegations and said the complaints were made with malicious intent. On Tuesday, members of Prahar Students Organisation and Nationalist Students Congress staged a protest at the college premises. “In spite of an FIR, the police have not taken any action and the college allows him to continue as principal,” said Ajay Tapkir, secretary, Prahar Students Organisation. The issue came to the fore earlier this month when Shiv Sena MLC Neelam Gorhe demanded his resignation. “The first complainant lost her job because she raised the issue. She has been following up on it since 2007 and has also written to the Prime Minister’s Office. The second complainant learnt of the first case and decided to speak up about the inappropriate behaviour at a conference,” said Gorhe. The principal told TOI: “It appears that a conspiracy has been hatched against me to tarnish my clean image. Earlier, the university’s women’s commission had dismissed such a complaint made by a teacher and hence she had filed a complaint with Tilak Nagar police station in 2018 for the alleged 2007 incident. In the second case, the person has filed a similar type of complaint in January 2019 for the alleged incident in October 2016. It’s obviously not a coincidence. I am being maliciously implicated by someone who wants to tarnish my image and the institution’s image. My innocence will be proved anyway but if such defamatory complaints are entertained, then there will be chaos in every organisation.” Juhu police senior inspector Pandrinath Wavhal said the case is under investigation and thus no details can be revealed. Copter service \u2018delayed\u2019, pilg.description: A 52-year-old pilgrim from Goregaon died in Uttarakhand as a helicopter allegedly took more than 45 minutes to ferry him from Kedarnath to a health centre in Guptakashi after he started feeling breatheless on Tuesday. Angry over the delay and death, the kin of the victim created ruckus at the helipad and had heated arguments with helicopter service providers who later went on strike for around two hours. The district administration has ordered an inquiry. Rudraprayag district magistrate Mangesh Ghildiyal said, “Vinod Vyas (52) complained of breathlessness in the temple after which he was taken to a health camp. The doctors referred him to a bigger health centre in Guptakashi. We immediately ordered the transportation of the victim but he died before he could have reached to the hospital,” the DM said. According to eyewitnesses, even after receiving the orders, the man remained on a stretcher near the helipad for over 30 minutes while Vyas’s kin argued with the helicopter service provider designated by the administration. “But the officials of the chopper service providers didn’t pay heed. It is only after the police intervened that they transported the man to Guptakshi, where he was declared brought dead by the doctors,” said a Rudraprayag cop. Chief medical officer Dr SK Jha said that it was a delay of around 30 minutes in the transportation of the elderly man. “He was very serious and we had asked for immediate referral,” he added. The district administration as well as police department have ordered an inquiry into the matter. “Circle Officer Kedarnath will be investigating the matter after which appropriate action will be taken,” said the DM. Another shaky bridge in Ghatkopar shut.description: MUMBAI: Monday brought good and bad news for Ghatkopar residents. The BMC barricaded a dilapidated bridge over Nilkanth nullah in Ghatkopar (E), but decided to re-open the one over Laxmi Baug nullah for light vehicles by month-end. The bridge over Nilkanth nullah is the 14th 'dangerous' bridge shut by the corporation in the last few months. Built in 1986, the bridge over Nilkanth nullah in Ghatkopar (E) is one of the connectors for local motorists heading towards Tilak Nagar in Chembur and Lokmanya Tilak Terminus in Kurla. "This bridge was one of the entry points into Ghatkopar, hence, traffic movement may take a hit for a few days," said local corporator Parag Shah. A senior civic official from the bridges department said this bridge had not made it to the initial list of 14 'dangerous' bridges. "The audit, carried out between 2016 and 2018, had stated that the bridge over Nilkanth nullah required major repairs. But the re-audit done after the fatal Himalaya foot over-bridge crash at CSMT in March declared this bridge dangerous. Hence, we decided to shut it," added the official. Shah said the BMC wanted to shut access to the bridge a few days back. "But we asked them to start the process for demolition and reconstruction first and then shut it, which it has done," he said. The decision to re-open the bridge over Laxmi Baug nullah for light vehicles is based on an IIT-B report. "We had sought the opinion of IIT-B experts, who, after an inspection, submitted a report recommending that the bridge could be opened for light vehicles by placing I-beams over the same steel plates," said a civic official. "We have already called an agency to procure the required material and begin the works on priority basis. We hope to allow light vehicles to ply on the bridge within a fortnight." Local NCP corporator Rakhi Jadhav said she had been urging the BMC to make arrangements and re-open the bridge, at least for light vehicles. Download The Times of India News App for Latest City .

Shiv Sena List 2019.description: MUMBAI: Shiv Sena has come up with it's first list of 21 candidates, out of 23 to contest in Lok Sabha polls in Maharashtra. Except Osmanabad, 17 sitting Sena MP's are part of the list, includes Mumbai, Thane, Kalyan, Raigad. Following complaints received by local functionaries from Osmanabad, the party has denied ticket to sitting MP Ravindra Gaikwad. Gaikwad, who had allegedly hit an Air India staffer with his slipper because he was refused a business class seat in March 2017. Maharashtra: Track here Lok Sabha elections' full coverageSena has kept two seats, Palghar and Satara, on hold, likely to announce on Sunday. Late Chintaman Wanga, former BJP MP's son Shrinivas likely to contest from Palghar on Sena ticket whereas former NCP legislator Narendra Patil may might contest as Sena candidate from Satara. Patil met Shiv Sena president Uddhav Thackeray on Friday at Matoshree. Other candidates are: South Mumbai: Arvind Sawant; South Central Mumbai: Rahul Shewale; Mumbai North West: Gajanan Kirtikar; Kalyan: Shrikant Shinde; Raigad: union minister Anant Gite; Osmanabad: Omraje Nimbalkar, Ratnagiri-Sindhudurg: Vinayak Raut; Kolhapur-Sanjay Mandlik; Hatkanangle: Dhairyasheel Mane; Nashik: Hemant Godse; Shirdi: Sadashiv Lokhande; Shirur: Shivajirao Adhalrao Patil; Aurangabad: Chandrakant Khaire; Yavatmal Washim: Bhawana Gawli; Buldana: Prataprao Jadhav; Ramtek: Kripal Tumane; Amrawati-Anandrao Adsul, Parbhani: Sanjay Jadhav; Maval: Shrirang Barne; Hingoli: Hemant Patil.
